Main Page | Namespace List | Class Hierarchy | Alphabetical List | Class List | File List | Namespace Members | Class Members | File Members

Scene Class Reference

#include <Scene.h>

Inheritance diagram for Scene:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

The scene is responsible for performing application operations (such as game state updates, collision calculations, network communication, etc.), and responsible for drawing the background of the desktop (e.g.

rendering the 3D scene).

Author:
Thomas Jacob

Definition at line 22 of file Scene.h.

Static Public Attributes

const int FORMAT_12BIT
 The color format that uses 12 bits for colors (typically 4/4/4 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_12BIT_WITH_ALPHA
 The color format that uses 12 bits for colors (typically 4/4/4 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 4) for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_15BIT
 The color format that uses 15 bits for colors (typically 5/5/5 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_15BIT_WITH_ALPHA
 The color format that uses 15 bits for colors (typically 5/5/5 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 1) for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_24BIT
 The color format that uses 24 bits for colors (typically 8/8/8 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_24BIT_WITH_ALPHA
 The color format that uses 24 bits for colors (typically 8/8/8 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 8) for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_8BIT
 The color format that uses 8 bits for colors (typically 3/3/2 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

const int FORMAT_8BIT_WITH_ALPHA
 The color format that uses 8 bits for colors (typically 3/3/2 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 8) for alpha information (blending).

const int KEEP_ADAPTER
 Return value of onEnter(), issueing that the new scene continues to use the current adapter settings.

const int RESTART_ADAPTER
 Return value of onEnter(), issueing that the platform adapter should shut down and initialize again, then using the new settings.

Member Function Documentation

void attachJoystickXMove (  int  eventNumber,
long  factor
) 
 

Sets, that x movements of the joystick shall increase or decrease certain event quantities.

Parameters:
eventNumber The number of the event for the joystick x movement.
factor The amount to increase the x event quantity for each x step. This number may be negative.
Note:
This method sets attachments that are applied in this scene only. If you wish to set a global, use the InputManager's attach method. Scene attachment always have a higher priority than global attachments.
See also:
InputManager

void attachJoystickXPosition (  int  eventNumber,
long  factor
) 
 

Sets, that the x position of the joystick shall set certain event quantities.

Parameters:
eventNumber The number of the event for the joystick x position.
factor The multiplier for the x position. This number may be negative.
Note:
This method sets attachments that are applied in this scene only. If you wish to set a global, use the InputManager's attach method. Scene attachment always have a higher priority than global attachments.
See also:
InputManager

long  factor
) 
 

Sets, that y movements of the joystick shall increase or decrease certain event quantities.

Parameters:
eventNumber The number of the event for the joystick y movement.
factor The amount to increase the y event quantity for each y step. This number may be negative.
Note:
This method sets attachments that are applied in this scene only. If you wish to set a global, use the InputManager's attach method. Scene attachment always have a higher priority than global attachments.
See also:

void attachKeyOrButton (  int  eventNumber,
int  keyCode,
int  type,
long  factor
) 
 

Sets, that a keyboard key shall raise a certain event if pressed, released or held.

To raise an event means to increase its quantity by a certain amount.

Parameters:
eventNumber The number of the event.
keyCode The key code that raises the event. This may include joystick and mouse buttons, specified using the key constants (e.g. KEY_JOYSTICK_BUTTON1 or KEY_MOUSE_LEFT).
type The type of key action to raise the event. Possible values are:
  • GFKC_HOLD: The event is raised while the key is held by factor for each milli second.
  • GFKC_PRESS: The event is raised once when the key is pressed.
  • GFKC_PRESSREPEAT: The event is raised when the key is pressed, and when held according to keyboard repetition (KeyboardRepeatDelay, KeyboardRepeatRate).
  • GFKC_RELEASE: The event is raised once when the key is released.
  • GFKC_PRESSRELEASE: The event is raised once when the key is pressed and once when released.

Parameters:
factor The amount to increase the event quantity in case of an event. This number may be negative.
Note:
This method sets attachments that are applied in this scene only. If you wish to set a global, use the InputManager's attach method. Scene attachment always have a higher priority than global attachments.
See also:
InputManager

void attachMouseWheel (  int  eventNumber,
long  factor
) 
 

Sets, that the mouse wheel movement shall increase a certain event quantity.

Parameters:
eventNumber The number of the event for the mouse wheel movement.
factor The amount to increase the event quantity for each step. This number may be negative.
Note:
This method sets attachments that are applied in this scene only. If you wish to set a global, use the InputManager's attach method. Scene attachment always have a higher priority than global attachments.
See also:
InputManager

void attachMouseXMove (  int  eventNumber,
long  factor
)

const ArrayList<Int>& getAcceptableFormats (   ) 
 

Returns the acceptable formats for all graphical surfaces.

Glaziery tries to find a matching resolution for a first format first, and if no resolution matches, it falls back to the second format, and so on. Defaults to FORMAT_24BIT, then FORMAT_15BIT, then FORMAT_8BIT.

Returns:
The acceptable formats for all graphical surfaces.

int getAttachmentKeyOrButton (  int  eventNumber,
bool  positive = true,
bool  negative = true
) 
 

Returns the key code of the attachment of a given event number.

Parameters:
eventNumber The number of the event.
positive Whether to search for attachments with positive factor. Defaults to true. May be combined with negative.
negative Whether to search for attachments with positive factor. Defaults to true. May be combined with positive.
Returns:
The key code of the attachment found, or -1 if no attachment or more than one attachment was found. The key may include joystick and mouse buttons, specified by the key code constants (e.g. KEY_JOYSTICK_BUTTON1 or KEY_MOUSE_LEFT).

unsigned int getDesiredHeight (   ) 
 

Returns the desired height of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 0, which means to try the current OS mode.

Returns:
The desired height.

Returns the desired refresh rate (in hertz) of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 0, which means to try the current OS mode.

Returns:
the desired refresh rate (in hertz).

unsigned int getDesiredWidth (   ) 
 

Returns the desired width of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 0, which means to try the current OS mode.

Returns:
The desired width.

virtual const char* getId (   )  [virtual]
 

Returns the unique ID of this scene.

This ID is used to select the scene when invoking Desktop::setScene() from any other operation, e.g. another scene's update() method.

Returns:
The unique ID of this scene.
Note:
Implement this method by return a constant int. This value should not change during the application's run. It is reasonable to provide a constant class field for other classes.
See also:
Desktop::setScene()

Returns:
The scene attachment.

unsigned int getMaximumHeight (   ) 
 

Returns the maximum acceptable height of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode above this value. Defaults to 768.

Returns:
The maximum acceptable height.

unsigned int getMaximumWidth (   ) 
 

Returns the maximum acceptable width of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode above this value. Defaults to 1024.

Returns:
The maximum acceptable width.

unsigned int getMinimumHeight (   ) 
 

Returns the minimum acceptable height of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode below this value. Defaults to 400.

Returns:
The minimum acceptable height.

unsigned int getMinimumWidth (   ) 
 

Returns the minimum acceptable width of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode below this value. Defaults to 600.

Returns:
The minimum acceptable width.

void* getModel (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Returns:
The application (or game) defined data.

SkinData* getSkinData (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Returns:
The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

void GlazieryObject::destructor (  void *  model  )  [static, inherited]
 

Destructor function for the setModel() method, when setting a model that is a glaziery object itself.

Parameters:
model The model to be destroyed.
See also:
setModel()

bool isConfigured (   ) 
 

Returns whether the configuration has been read successfully.

Returns:
Whether the configuration has been read successfully.

bool isExclusive (   ) 
 

Returns whether the application (or game) shall run in exclusive mode.

All system resources are used exclusively by the application. This flag also requires the fullScreen flag to be set, which is set automatically. Defaults to false.

Warning:
Do not use exclusive mode before the application works fine. If it hangs, you have to reboot the computer.

bool isFullScreen (   ) 
 

Returns whether the application (or game) shall run in full screen mode, rather than in a window.

It displays the graphics output to the full screen. If exclusive is not specified, the other system resources are still shared with the other applications. Defaults to false for debug and true for release builds.

bool isHardwareTnLDesirable (   ) 
 

Returns whether the game uses transform and lighting while processing vertexes (3D games usually do), so that hardware TnL is desirable.

If the game does not use it, the framework might choose software TnL to find a better resolution for the game. Defaults to true.

Returns:
Whether the game uses transform and lighting.

virtual int onEnter (   )  [virtual]
 

Performs operations when the scene has been set, before render() or update() is next called.

This method is called each time the scene is set. The method is called by the desktop, so do not call it manually.

Returns:
Whether to restart the platform adapter, because the new scene requires a different graphics setup. If KEEP_ADAPTER is returned, the new scene continues to use the current settings. If RESTART_ADAPTER is returned, the platform adapter is shut down and initialized again, then using the new settings. Windows and other components are not closed automatically, but some sub-systems may have reset, depending on the implementation of the platform adapter.
Note:
Perform all each-time initialization operations here when the scene is set. The default implementation does nothing and returns KEEP_ADAPTER.
See also:
onExit()

Desktop::setScene()

virtual void onExit (   )  [virtual]
 

Performs operations when the scene is unset, e.g.

because another scene is set, or because the Desktop shuts down. In the latter case, this method is called before onShutDown. The method is called by the desktop, so do not call it manually.

Note:
Perform all each-time shut down operations here when the scene is unset. The default implementation does nothing.
See also:
onEnter()

onShutDown()

Desktop::setScene()

virtual void onInitialize (  bool  firstRun  )  [virtual]
 

Performs operations to initialize the scene on Desktop initialization.

This method is called after the skin and platform adapter have been initialized, so they are already available, and it is called only once. The method is called by the desktop, so do not call it manually.

Note:
Perform all one-time initialization operations here that require an initialized platform adapter (such as image or font retrieval). The default implementation does nothing.
See also:
onShutDown()

Desktop::createInstance()

PlatformAdapter

Skin

virtual void onShutDown (   )  [virtual]
 

Performs operations to shut down the scene on Desktop shut down.

This method is called before the skin and platform adapter are shut down, so they are still available, and it is called only once. The method is called by the desktop, so do not call it manually.

Note:
Perform all one-time shut down operations here that require an initialized platform adapter. The default implementation does nothing.
See also:
onInitialize(bool firstRun)

Desktop::destroyInstance()

PlatformAdapter

Skin

virtual void renderBackground (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual]
 

Displays the desktop background for the current frame, behind all windows and popups.

The default implementation clears the device.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Note:
Implement this method to write your main displaying routines. These routine shall draw to the Direct3D device. Glaziery displays windows on top of this background and then performs the Direct3DDevice::Present(). BeginScene(), Clear(), and EndScene() is also handled by Glaziery.

virtual void renderForeground (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual]
 

Displays the desktop foreground for the current frame, in front of all windows and popups.

The default implementation does nothing.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Note:
Implement this method to write your main displaying routines. These routine shall draw to the Direct3D device. Glaziery displays windows on top of this background and then performs the Direct3DDevice::Present(). BeginScene(), Clear(), and EndScene() is also handled by Glaziery.

void setAcceptableFormats (  int *  acceptableFormats,
int  length
) 
 

Sets the acceptable formats for all graphical surfaces.

Glaziery tries to find a matching resolution for a first format first, and if no resolution matches, it falls back to the second format, and so on. Defaults to FORMAT_24BIT, then FORMAT_15BIT, then FORMAT_8BIT.

Parameters:
acceptableFormats An array of acceptable formats.
length The length of the acceptableFormats array.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 600.

desiredHeight The desired height.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 80.

Parameters:
desiredRefreshRate the desired refresh rate (in hertz).

void setDesiredWidth (  unsigned int  desiredWidth  ) 
 

Sets the desired width of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 800.

Parameters:
desiredWidth The desired width.

void setExclusive (  bool  exclusive  ) 
 

Sets whether the application (or game) shall run in exclusive mode.

All system resources are used exclusively by the application. This flag also requires the fullScreen flag to be set, which is set automatically. Defaults to false.

Warning:
Do not use exclusive mode before the application works fine. If it hangs, you have to reboot the computer.
Parameters:
exclusive Whether the application shall run in exclusive mode.

void setFullScreen (  bool  fullScreen  ) 
 

Sets whether the application (or game) shall run in full screen mode, rather than in a window.

It displays the graphics output to the full screen. If exclusive is not specified, the other system resources are still shared with the other applications. Defaults to false for debug and true for release builds.

Parameters:
fullScreen Whether the application shall run in full screen mode.

void setHardwareTnLDesirable (  bool  hardwareTnLDesirable  ) 
 

Sets whether the game uses transform and lighting while processing vertexes (3D games usually do), so that hardware TnL is desirable.

If the game does not use it, the framework might choose software TnL to find a better resolution for the game. Defaults to true.

Parameters:
hardwareTnLDesirable Whether the game uses transform and lighting.

void setMaximumHeight (  unsigned int  maximumHeight  ) 
 

Sets the maximum acceptable height of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode above this value. Defaults to 768.

Parameters:
maximumHeight The maximum acceptable height.

void setMaximumWidth (  unsigned int  maximumWidth  ) 
 

Sets the maximum acceptable width of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode above this value. Defaults to 1024.

Parameters:
maximumWidth The maximum acceptable width.

void setMinimumHeight (  unsigned int  minimumHeight  ) 
 

Sets the minimum acceptable height of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode below this value. Defaults to 400.

Parameters:
minimumHeight The minimum acceptable height.

void setMinimumWidth (  unsigned int  minimumWidth  ) 
 

Sets the minimum acceptable width of the full screen resolution or the display window.

The framework will not open a mode below this value. Defaults to 600.

Parameters:
minimumWidth The minimum acceptable width.

void setModel (  void *  model,
void(*  modelDestructor)(void *model) = NULL
)  [inherited]
 

Sets the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Parameters:
model The application (or game) defined data.
modelDestructor An optional static method that is called, whenever the glaziery object is destroyed or when a new model is set. Specify this function only, if the model must be destroyed by this glaziery object, i.e. the object "owns" the model. If the model is a glaziery object itself, you may use the GlazieryObject::destructor() function.
See also:
destructor()

virtual void setSkinData (  SkinData *  skinData  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Sets the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Parameters:
skinData The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

Any previously set skin data is automatically destroyed.

Reimplemented in Component.

virtual String toString (   )  [virtual]
 

Returns a string reprensentation of this object.

Returns:
The string representation.

Reimplemented from GlazieryObject.

virtual void update (   )  [virtual]
 

Updates internal variables and performs application operations, such as game state updates, collision calculations, network communication, etc.

Note:
Implement this method to write your main operational routines. The default implementation does nothing.

Member Data Documentation

ArrayList<Int> acceptableFormats [private]
 

The acceptable formats for all graphical surfaces.

Glaziery tries to find a matching resolution for a first format first, and if no resolution matches, it falls back to the second format, and so on. Defaults to FORMAT_24BIT, then FORMAT_15BIT, then FORMAT_8BIT.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 600.

The framework tries to get as close as possible to this value. Defaults to 80.

Definition at line 75 of file Scene.h.

const int FORMAT_12BIT [static]
 

The color format that uses 12 bits for colors (typically 4/4/4 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

Definition at line 171 of file Scene.h.

const int FORMAT_12BIT_WITH_ALPHA [static]
 

The color format that uses 12 bits for colors (typically 4/4/4 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 4) for alpha information (blending).

Definition at line 177 of file Scene.h.

const int FORMAT_15BIT [static]
 

The color format that uses 15 bits for colors (typically 5/5/5 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

Definition at line 159 of file Scene.h.

const int FORMAT_15BIT_WITH_ALPHA [static]
 

The color format that uses 15 bits for colors (typically 5/5/5 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 1) for alpha information (blending).

Definition at line 165 of file Scene.h.

const int FORMAT_24BIT [static]
 

The color format that uses 24 bits for colors (typically 8/8/8 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

The color format that uses 24 bits for colors (typically 8/8/8 for R/G/B), and extra bits (typically 8) for alpha information (blending).

Definition at line 153 of file Scene.h.

const int FORMAT_8BIT [static]
 

The color format that uses 8 bits for colors (typically 3/3/2 for R/G/B), but no bits for alpha information (blending).

Definition at line 110 of file Scene.h.

const int RESTART_ADAPTER [static]
 

Return value of onEnter(), issueing that the platform adapter should shut down and initialize again, then using the new settings.

Windows and other components are not closed automatically, but some sub-systems may have reset, depending on the implementation of the platform adapter.

Definition at line 203 of file Scene.h.

The scene attachments set.

Global attachments are managed by the InputManager.
